titlepage.titleproper: Inventory for the Benjamin H. Grierson Papers, 1827-1941 and undated
titlepage.author: Abel Ramirez

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Benjamin Henry Grierson Papers, 1827-1941 and undated
did.abstract: The papers of Benjamin Henry Grierson, a major general of volunteers who went on to be Superintendent of the General Mounted Recruiting Service in Saint Louis, Missouri from 1873-1874 and later commanded several forts in Texas.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library, Texas Tech University

bioghist.head: Biographical Sketch
bioghist.p: Benjamin Henry Grierson was born on July 8, 1826 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He was the youngest son of Robert and Mary (Shepard) Grierson, who were born and married in Dublin, Ireland. Robert and Mary emigrated to the United States after the birth of their second child. Other children born to Robert and Mary were Louisa, who married Mr. Semple, and John C.

Benjamin attended the Yorktown, Ohio, Academy. In Youngstown, Ohio, he married Alice Kirk on September 24, 1854. Together, they had seven children: Charles Henry, who entered the army and attended West Point; John Kirk; Robert Kirk, who attended medical school and suffered from mental illness at various times; Edith Clare; Benjamin Henry Jr.; George Theodore; and Mary Louisa. After Alice's death in 1888, Benjamin married the widow Lillian Atwood King in 1897.

From 1849-1855, he taught music in Jacksonville, Illinois, and was a partner in a Meredosia store from 1855-1859. During the Civil War, Grierson became a major general of volunteers and was appointed Colonel of the 10th Regiment of Cavalry, U. S. Army, in July of 1866. From 1866-1867, he was stationed at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas. Afterwards, he commanded Fort Riley, Kansas (September 1867-April 1868), Fort Gibson, Camp Wichita, Fort Sill, and Indian Territory (1868-1873) before serving as Superintendent of the General Mounted Recruiting Service in Saint Louis, Missouri from 1873-1874. Grierson also commanded Fort Concho, Texas, and the District of the Pecos from 1875-1881; Fort Concho and sub posts from 1881-1882; the Department of Texas in 1883; Fort Davis, Texas, sub posts and country west of the Pecos River from 1883-1885; and Whipple Barracks, Prescott, Arizona Territory from 1885-1890. In 1890, General Grierson retired to his ranch in Jeff Davis County, Texas, and had a home at Fort Davis. He died on September 1, 1911.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes correspondence, financial material, genealogical material, legal material, literary productions, military materials, photographs, printed and scrapbook material. It bulks (1827-1941) with Benjamin Grierson's personal correspondence dealing with family matters, special occasions and hunting trips.

The materials are arranged into 5 major sections: Benjamin H. Grierson, 1827-1941; Charles H. Grierson (Benjamin Grierson's oldest son), 1889-1939; Mason M. Maxon (Captain, 10th Cavalry), 1869-1899; Robert G. Smithers (Adjutant, 10th Cavalry), 1862-1922; Henry C. Smithers (son of Robert Smithers), 1914-1922. The Microfilm includes Army Ordinance files, music books, genealogical history, Grierson's Army records, military correspondence, autobiography, two bound books, Lights and Shadows (1892), and a letter copy book by John Kirk, Texas Letters.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: The subject headings used by the Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library are derived from the Library of Congress and/or locally developed.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Benjamin H. Grierson Papers, 1827-1941 and undated, Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, Texas
